# packages/adapter-rust/vendor/codelldb/darwin-arm64/lldb/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pip/_vendor/rich/_palettes.py
@source-hash: 71d7afd4940a6742
@generated: 2026-02-09T17:58:59Z

## Primary Purpose

This module defines pre-configured color palettes for the Rich library's color rendering system. It provides standardized RGB color mappings for different terminal color schemes and ANSI color standards.

## Key Components

### WINDOWS_PALETTE (L5-24)
16-color palette based on Windows 10 ANSI escape code colors. Contains RGB tuples for standard and bright variants of the 8 basic ANSI colors, optimized for Windows terminal appearance.

### STANDARD_PALETTE (L27-46) 
Standard 16-color ANSI palette with traditional RGB values. Includes both normal (colors 0-7) and bright (colors 8-15) variants following classic ANSI color specifications.

### EIGHT_BIT_PALETTE (L50-309)
Complete 256-color palette for 8-bit color mode. Structure:
- Colors 0-15: Standard ANSI colors (duplicated from 16-color palettes)
- Colors 16-231: 6x6x6 RGB color cube with values at intervals of 40 (0, 95, 135, 175, 215, 255)
- Colors 232-255: Grayscale ramp from dark to light

## Dependencies

- `Palette` class from `.palette` module (L1) - wraps RGB tuple lists into palette objects

## Architecture Notes

- All palettes use RGB tuples with 8-bit values (0-255)
- Color ordering follows ANSI standards for compatibility
- Windows palette provides platform-specific color accuracy
- 8-bit palette enables full terminal color range support
- Static data structure - no runtime color computation

## Usage Context

These palettes serve as lookup tables for converting color indices to RGB values in terminal rendering, ensuring consistent color representation across different terminal environments and color depth capabilities.
